"Blitz? What's wrong?" He asked, looking up at the big face, his expression twisted into an irritated sneer, his brown eyes narrowed and his muzzle contorted.

"Snowball?" Alex repeated, his face shifting into a bewildered expression which quickly changed into one of shocked awe as he turned to from the towering canine to face along the beach.

Walking along the beach was another dog, clearly, another Road Rover judging by his bipedal stance and the heavy armour that he wore across his powerful frame. The canine possessed a most intriguing fur pattern; his face and, presumably, his underside were a stark, pristine white whereas the rest of his fur was darker, appearing almost blue. Given his strong, broad frame and the thickness of his fur, Alex figured the new arrival was a Husky. However, the most striking thing about the Husky was, without a shadow of a doubt, his size.

The Husky was a giant. There was simply no other way to describe him. Not only did he exceed Blitz in height, but the naturally broader frame of Huskies also made him quite a bit bigger, which only served to further exemplify his extraordinary physique.

The Husky suddenly stumbled to a stop as he caught sight of Blitz, his eyes widening in an expression of surprise, relief and what appeared to be anxiety. He quickly rushed up, the heavy pounding of his footsteps reverberating throughout the clear sea air.

"Blitz! There you are!" He furiously barked out, the bass and volume of his voice causing Alex to instinctively flinch. The Husky snarled something in a language he didn't understand, but the harsh tone and enraged expression left no doubt that the phrase was most certainly not a compliment.

"What were you thinking, you idiot?! As if people weren't going to panic at a giant dog-man walking around! How tall are you anyway? It must be 30 feet!" He growled, diverting to look himself over for a moment. "Must make me about 40 feet." He mused, before shaking his head and continuing, the volume of his voice rising back to its previous volume of an enraged bellow. "How did, how could you think this was a good idea? And we've still got that huge hole in your roof at Headquarters, how are we going to fix that without giving this all away?!" He roared, his face contorted into a snarl or furious rage, to the point where even Blitz looked as if he was struggling to hold his composure, although Alex had to admit, it was nothing short of truly heroic that Blitz had stood with his back ramrod straight throughout the whole of the massive Husky's outburst.

The enormous Husky closed his eyes and inhaled, his cavernous chest expanding impressively, to the point where Alex could have sworn he heard the thick armour he was wearing let out a low groan of protest. The Husky exhaled and opened his eyes to continue his furious tirade. Then he caught sight of Alex and his eyes widened in horror.

"Uh, hi there." He managed to spit out, grinning up at the huge Husky bashfully.

"Blitz." He started slowly, cautiously. "You, you've..." He stammered.

"Ja. This is Alex. I scared off some fool who was trying to mug him, just by standing there!" Blitz boasted.

"What! Blitz, you, what if he talks?" He cried, to which Blitz raised his other paw reassuringly.

"Look, even if he did, there's no evidence, right? No one would believe him, and he'd have to make sure he left out the mugging, so that'd be another problem for him. Trust me, it'll be fine!"

The Husky put a huge paw to his snout, furrowing his brow for a moment before he let out a sigh. "Alright. Fine." He conceded. He removed the paw from his snout and looked down at Alex. "Hello there comrade. My name is Exile, you may know of me? I'm a Road Rover, like Blitz. Um, sorry about that, I sort of misplaced my temper." He grinned nervously.

"You mean you lost your temper." Blitz corrected, to a quizzical look from Exile. He shook his head and motioned for him to continue.

"It, it's alright. I remember you, you guys were a lot more active in my younger years. Uh, how did you get so big though?" Alex interrupted.

"Oh! Well, um..." Exile started, his ears flattening against his skull. "Well, um, you know how I have vision powers to go along with my strength, da? Well, this morning, I woke up and I find I have new vision powers!" He beamed. "I can make things and people bigger or smaller!"

"Whoa." Alex breathed. "That's incredible. I'd ask how, but considering you're walking, talking superpowered canines..." He trailed off, taking in both of their forms.

The both of them chuckled lightly, dispelling the tension that had been present. "Da. It is true. But, I'm afraid I can't keep to chat. Blitz, please, we have to go back to Headquarters! If the others see we're missing, if they haven't already, they'll ask questions, and there's the hole in the roof..." Exile pleaded with him.

Blitz let out a sigh. "Look, Exile. If I go back, I'll have to shrink. I don't want to shrink! I feel incredible! I feel like I could bicep curl a mountain range!" He grinned, flexing a bicep in response, the huge, solid muscle swelling outwards, straining the softer, more flexible fabric of his armour, which audibly groaned in protest.

Exile averted his gaze for a moment as he admitted. "Da. I usually feel big and powerful, comes with being a Husky, living in Siberia, and just really being big and powerful, even before super strength comes to play." He paused. "I usually feel hot, sweaty and large, but now I feel hot, sweaty, giant, and well, unstoppable!" He smiled softly, which faded as quickly as it appeared. "But, I can't stay like this. We can't stay like this."

"Well, can't we stay like this just a bit longer?" Blitz asked. "I never even got to get to know Alex here."

"Well, um, I could come back here tomorrow, if you'd like? I can meet you here Blitz? I'd hate to be a bother." Alex interjected, eliciting a thoughtful expression from the towering Doberman as he pondered his options.

Exile ran a paw over his muzzle as he thought back to the whole mess Blitz had gotten them into. He looked over at the Doberman from across the table, who was currently downing a Peppermint Milkshake, although the expression in his eyes belied his casual, relaxed posture. It had been an incredibly stressful time while the pair frantically raced to repair the holes in the roof of his quarters. They'd been extremely lucky they not only had Blitz been standing away from pipes and wiring, but that they could salvage a good deal of the roofing from the roof it had been pushed up into and the floor it had fallen to, or else their entire plan would have collapsed right then and there. As if that hadn't been difficult enough to handle, they'd had to scramble to figure out a way to make the ceiling look as if it hadn't just been smashed through by a Doberman, who, not even including a humanoid posture, sentience, and superpowers, had grown to a size that shouldn't have been possible. It had been more of a dash-slap job, or however it went, rather than a professional job, but a bit more work should sort it. He hoped.

He shook his head and looked down at his coffee. He couldn't find the stomach to drink it, not after how his heart raced when the Master had stopped by to ask about some odd environmental readings that he'd finally decided he should check out after explaining something about programs and variables. He still wasn't convinced that the Master really believed them when they insisted that it had to be a fluke, but after checking in and seeing no outside light streaming in and that the room temperature was not, in fact, the same as the outside, even if it was a little cool, he had finally seemed mollified, leaving with an apology and a perplexed expression at his tablet. He grimaced at the thought, hoping that was the end of his suspicions. However, there was still the issue of Blitz planning to go and meet that Alex again. He looked back up at the Doberman. "Blitz." He finally said, after a long silence.

Blitz paused, setting his drink down on the counter and swallowing his mouthful of beverage. "Ja?" He replied, ears perked. "Listen, I need to ask you something." He said, but Blitz frowned, raising a paw and speaking before he could continue. "Look, Exile, I'm going to stop you right there. I'm willing to have a nice, polite chat with each other about anything, except for enjoying that growth so much. Ja, I loved it. I adored it. But, if you're about to ask me about it and harass me over it, I'll go enjoy my drink elsewhere, ja? I'm not trying to be rude or anything, but I just want you to keep that in mind." He explained. Exile clasped his hands together, bracing his elbows on the counter and leaning forward. Interesting. He hadn't been going to mention that, but Blitz certainly seemed a bit insecure, or maybe anxious was the right term, about it. "Nyet, nyet, it is not that, well, it's kind of that, but not about the growing and getting big part in particular." He reassured him, to which the Doberman instantly seemed to relax, his shoulders dropped and he exhaled through his nose. "Alright then, that's good to hear. What was it you wanted to ask?"

The Husky paused, trying to think of the best way to phrase the question while still getting to the point. "Well, it's about that human. Alex." He explained, to which Blitz cocked his head in confusion. "What about him?" He asked warily, to which Exile frowned, considering his response. "Well, you seemed very eager to talk to him again. What is up with that? I thought you were interested in Colleen?" He asked, briefly considering taking a jab at her rejections. While they were typically a bit aggressive, and maybe a bit too violent at times, they were sometimes also highly amusing to listen to and watch. However, if he did so, and Blitz took offense, which was all but guaranteed, then he might just shut down or walk away, and he'd lose his only chance to find out what he wanted to know. Blitz was quiet for a split second longer than usual before he replied, although he felt that it was a bit too quick at the beginning as if he'd scrambled for an answer. "Uh, well, he's an interesting fellow, I don't know him too well, but I want to. I mean, I saved his life, and he was really grateful, and I enjoyed his company." He replied, nodding at the end.

Exile was silent as he mulled over Blitz's response. He nodded while looking directly at him to signify he had heard and understood his response and wasn't simply ignoring him. It almost seemed as though Blitz really was interested in getting to know Alex better. He was no interrogator but the look in his eyes that he had attempted to hide and his tone of voice told him everything he needed to know. Blitz seemed genuinely interested in Alex. Exile refused the urge to put his head in his hands or growl. It wasn't that he was opposed to the idea of Blitz making friends, Blitz could absolutely do with someone to help bring out his more positive attributes. It was more the fact that Blitz was trying to make friends with a human. Again, that would be fine, except for the not inconsequential fact that he was a Road Rover, and their headquarters was supposed to be more or less secret to prevent retaliation. He tried to think of how exactly he was going to tell Blitz that he wasn't sure this was a great idea without sounding like he was being rude or insensitive. That would probably just get him an angry glare and a biting remark before he stalked off in a foul mood.

"Comrade..." He started hesitantly. "I do not wish to intrude or be a problem, but, well, er, don't take this the wrong way, but are you sure about this?" He asked, quickly continuing at Blitz's surprised expression. "I mean, it is you meeting a human, which is fine, except we don't really know anything about him. Are you sure this is a good idea? So many things could go so badly wrong, especially when we take my, um, well, growing and shrinking powers into the photo?" He asked. Blitz furrowed his brow as he rolled his eyes. "Ja, Exile. I know we don't know anything about him really, that's literally the whole point of me going out to meet him. Furthermore, I'm sure I can trust him, I mean, I saved his life. He was about to get stabbed by a mugger when he didn't have any money on him. What if he got stabbed in the lung? In the heart? What if it cut an artery or something? He would have bled to death long before an ambulance could ever arrive. I'm pretty sure he's fine." He explained curtly.

Exile promptly raised his hands in a placating gesture. "Whoa, easy there Blitz, I didn't mean it like that. Look, I just want to make sure that you're not going to end up making a mistake." He explained, before quickly realising that might rile his temper. "Um, and I also don't want to wind up causing bigger problems with my new tricks." He said quickly. Blitz frowned, looking into his milkshake for a few moments. "Look, I get that." He finally admitted. "But, well, uh, look, I'm sure I'll be fine. And, you know, you're the only one who can actually make people grow or shrink, so it's sure to be just fine. I mean, don't get me wrong, being so big is amazing! I get to show off how big and strong and handsome I am!" He boasted, his back straightening as he smirked proudly, flexing a bicep confidently, drawing a slight grin from Exile in response as a bit of Blitz's self-assurance came back. "But, you're the only one who can make me bigger, so if you're really, really, really sure that that's not a good idea at some point, you don't have to. Remember, no one knows about this except us." He reminded him, before grimacing slightly. "Although, I guess you'll have to say something sooner or later." He pointed out. Exile grimaced this time, knowing he was right. He'd never be able to hide this forever, surely. They'd only gotten away with it by sheer luck. "Master would want to know how it works. I'm not supposed to have this power, or I wasn't supposed to at least." He admitted sombrely.

Damn it, the conversation had been turned around on him. Now, what was he going to do? He wasn't in the mood to get into an awkward conversation on something as serious and important as that. Thankfully, however, he was spared from that as Blitz decided it was time to take his leave. "Well, I should leave you to it, that's some pretty serious stuff to think about, I'll let you think in peace." He said, surprisingly softly and civilly. With that, he gulped down his milkshake, and Exile watched as Blitz strolled over to the fridge and promptly made himself another milkshake, before leaving in the direction of his room.

Exile went to lean back, before remembering that he was sitting on a stool, not a chair. Grinning sheepishly at the near-miss, he pushed himself up and decided to go sit down in one of the chairs. It was quiet in here, and right now, that was exactly what he needed. He grabbed the back of a chair and began to pull it out when he nearly leapt out of his armour when a near deafening squawk hit his ears. He yelled in surprise as he whipped around, looking for the source of the noise, bringing his hands up when he realised that he was holding the back of the chair in his hand. He blinked down at it, turning to see that he had accidentally torn the chair in two. He chuckled in embarrassment as he realised that his superhuman strength had simply torn the metal apart without even trying. He looked up to see what the source of the noise was and noted the police scanner lying on the end of the table. Someone must have left it on.

He stepped forward, reaching for the switch when a voice spoke from the scanner. "83-32, we have reports of a 10-33 approximately two blocks from your location. That's a 10-33. We have reports that there is at least one occupant still in the house. Fire and EMS are en-route, head to the scene for traffic control. All other units in the area, standby for a more precise address and prepare to assist if requested. Over." Exile grimaced, taking a moment to hope that whoever was in that house would be okay, before the scanner came back to life, the dispatcher providing the address. He grimaced again. It was close by. Very close by actually. It would take maybe 10 minutes to get there by car if he hurried. But, the Fire Department had it under control, surely? They may be superheroes, but there were still emergency services, they could take care of themselves.

Then the address came over the scanner. Exile growled, a deep, rumbling growl of frustration. Of course it was so close by. The emergency services could surely take care of it easily. It was a house fire. It wasn't Cano-mutants tearing tanks apart and shrugging off machine gun fire. It probably wasn't a major criminal plot. It was a simple house fire. But he was so close, and it would be wrong to just go to bed and go to sleep while someone choked in their own home, waiting for help as the flames crept closer and the smoke grew thicker, blacker, deadlier...

He whimpered softly as he shivered. He could start fires easily himself, his heat vision could literally melt metal. He knew far better than many of the sheer destructive potential of fire, and how dangerous it could be. He shook his head. He should go. He was only going to hate himself if he didn't, and he wasn't going to get anything done standing around like an idiot. But first, he had to be prepared. He quickly ran through a list of what to take. He'd need a mirror to let him grow himself, he had no idea if it would work if he just focused his power on his arm or something - or why it reflected in the first place now that he thought about it, although that was a question for later- but he couldn't chance it. He'd naturally need SCBA gear, his super strength and vision powers didn't make him immune to smoke and toxic fumes. Ah, and he'd need to figure out how he was going to get there. He could run at breath-taking speeds to most people, but he was nowhere near as fast as Hunter, so a vehicle it was.

He rushed to his room, pulling open the vanity drawer, pushing things out of the way until he could grab hold of a handheld mirror. It was a very ornate piece, clean glass surrounded by gleaming golden metal which was adorned with exquisite, detailed patterns - snaking spirals and rolling waves. It was gorgeous. So much so that he almost didn't want to take it, but the thought of someone dying because he wasted time on something so petty immediately shot that idea down. Slamming the drawer shut again, he took off for the vehicle bay.

Slipping through the door, he made a beeline for the lockers, almost yanking the door open before thinking better of it. He didn't want to waste time by tearing the door off and fumbling in an attempt to put it back. Grabbing the SCBA gear, he hoisted it over his shoulder, turning towards the vehicle bays.

What he saw made him freeze. Blitz was standing next to the Street Rover, a thoughtful look across his muzzle. "Blitz?" He asked, furrowing his brow. The Doberman let out a gasp as he whipped around. "Ah, Exile! I was thinking of going out, although now that you're here, if it's not too much trouble, could I bother you... Hey, what's with the oxygen tank?" He asked, trailing off mid-sentence as Exile stepped closer, allowing him to get a better look at him.

"I'm on my way to a fire, someone needs help." He explained, to which Blitz's eyes widened slightly. "Oh. I see. But, can't the Fire Department take care of it themselves? Unless there's canomutants there, they shouldn't need our help, and are you sure about going alone?" He asked. Exile blinked. Blitz was seeming rather... not quite caring, but certainly less self-centered than usual. He shook his head and cleared his thoughts. There wasn't time for that now. "Da, but I am going anyway. I want to help, besides I will be fine on my own." He reassured him. "Before I go, what was it that you wanted anyway?" He asked.

Blitz looked away for a moment. "Ah, well, you see, I was going to ask if you could, you know, make me a bit bigger again, but I guess you're in a rush so..." He trailed off as Exile frowned a bit. Of course. It made sense, of course Blitz would want to be bigger. He felt a flicker of annoyance, although his more rational side conceded that he enjoyed being huge too. He was already a real powerhouse, he was reminded of his size and powerful build every time he slipped into his armour. Being so much bigger amplified all those feelings, and he could only imagine how much greater the amplification was for Blitz. At least he wasn't trying to block him from leaving. "Well, alright, I can make you a bit bigger, but I'm only doing it for a few seconds." He answered, his tone leaving no room for argument.

Blitz raised his hands in reassurance. "Well, I mean, I'd love that ja, but if you're really in a rush..." He started but trailed off as Exile narrowed his eyes in a way that almost made him look intimidating - although the Husky's natural bulk was part of the reason too - before a thick purple beam came from his eyes and hit the Doberman square in the chest.

Blitz let out a gasp as his entire frame began to surge upwards and outwards, rising higher by the second.

Obviously, he needed to get out as quickly as possible. Just because he had managed to put the fire out, it didn't magically clear the smoke away, and given how that was what usually killed people in fires, getting him into fresh air was the top priority. Glancing down at the man, Exile yanked his SCBA mask off. He was immediately stuck by the intensity of the smoke. As if he didn't have enough to deal with, he already felt like he was nearly roasting with the sheer heat. At the best of times, he was still usually hot, his thick fur and his sheer bulk saw to that. He shook his head and growled before slipping the mask back on and drawing in a few breaths of air, preparing himself before he pulled the mask off again and placed it over the mans head, forcing oxygen into his lungs.

He kept the mask over the man's face for a few more seconds until he couldn't hold his breath any more. With his lungs burning with the need to get all of the carbon dioxide out of his system, he yanked the mask off and put it back over his face. Exile flinched as a rush of heat suddenly struck him. He immediately curled around the man to protect him from the backdraft he feared was coming, but thankfully, there was no fireball. Tentatively looking back, he could see the floor had been more or less burned through from below, judging by the scorch marks on the walls, and it looked like there was traces of some sort of gas explosion. He could see that there was no chance of getting the man across the gap. The entire floor was gone. He had to get him out somehow. He scowled in a mixture of anger and fear.

Unless he had a stride of about 12 feet he was never going to make it across that gap. Exile froze, a thrill running through him as he was struck by the realisation that he actually could have a stride of 12 feet, and even more! He reached for his pocket and yanked the mirror out. Unsure if the mask would interfere with his vision, he pulled it off, grimacing as he did so and blasted his vision into the mirror.

His powerful frame began to bulge outwards, swelling larger by the second. As his ears crept closer to the ceiling he could feel the floor beneath his feet struggle under his weight. A soft creaking sounded out which rose into a series of sharp, harsh cracks. He quickly stepped over to the door and realised that his ears could brush the underside of the top of the doorframe. Then, a couple of seconds later, his ears were pressing into it, and then they were flattened against his head. He ducked through and, as gently as he could, lowered himself to the floor below. As he dropped down, he stumbled. His foot had punched straight through the floor. He gawked at the sight, startled by his tremendous weight. He pulled his foot out and staggered back, letting out a gasp as he hit the wall behind him and dented it, although that was putting it lightly. The wall had nearly collapsed under him, with huge cracks spreading through the plaster. He pulled forward and turned to face the dent, to find his ears brushing the little bit of the walkway above. He stooped down to look up and realised with a start that he was already 10 feet tall, rapidly going on 11. He frowned at the smoke above. He'd been lucky so far, but he didn't want to risk it. He looked down at his mask and used his vision on it as well, growing it up to where he could take a few more deep breaths. After a few long, precious seconds of this, he pulled it off and glanced back at the ornate mirror in his hand. Another use of his vision, and he was growing again.

As he glanced up from the mirror slightly, he was startled to see what little remained of the floor above drop down to be level with his nose. As he watched, he could see the floor sink lower and lower with every passing second, going from being level with his nose to being level with his chin. A moment later it was level with his neck, and a moment after that it was level with his muscular chest. He shook himself from his daze. Now was neither the time nor the place to get lost in his growth, as incredible as it was. He glanced down, past his thick, powerful legs, to see the floor, 14 feet below. He could feel the floorboards beneath his huge paws groan and warp, straining under his weight. He felt a pang of anxiety as he wondered if the house had a basement. He couldn't even begin to estimate his weight, but he was easily more than twice as tall as he usually was, so if he was correct, he had to weigh at least a ton now.

He brought up a hand and ran it over his muzzle, before he found himself in a coughing fit. He crouched down, ignoring the distressing groans of the floor beneath his immense bulk and reached up to wave the smoke away as best he could. He stood back up, raising a hand up and staring in awe as his hand touched the ceiling. He barely had to reach up. He was massive now, a literal giant. Yet he was still getting bigger. He shook his head in muted awe, looking towards the door to where the victim was lying. He brought up a bulky arm to reach for him, only to pause as he tried to stick his hand through and realised that his arm was, quite literally, too big to fit through. The thick, muscular limb simply couldn't properly fit through the doorway. He'd grown to get him out of the house, and now he couldn't get him out of the room. He withdrew his arm, barking out a curse. His thoughts raced as he tried to figure out what to do.

With a growl of almost pure frustration, he reached forwards and jammed his fingers into the doorframe. He was just about to violently pull his hands apart before he realised that he was putting his strength into focus. If he tried to violently pull the wall apart with his full strength behind it, he'd probably utterly atomise the entire building, if not the whole street effortlessly. With a much more gently hold, he prised the doorframe apart with his hands. Huge, intimidating cracks shot out from the doorframe and spread through the plaster as the wooden frame splintered and fractured instantly, laughably pathetic in the face of such sheer power. The ceiling jolted as the wall crumbled under his grip, leaving a large hole. Large enough to get at least one hand through to the man easily.

Shoving a hand through, he gently grabbed a hold of the man, curling his hand around him gently. He was grateful that he was suffering from smoke inhalation and not something like a broken bone. It meant that he could afford to be ever so slightly less careful in moving him and put more focus into simply getting out. As he withdrew his hand, he pulled the smaller man through and leant in, his massive muzzle gently brushing over him. He was still alive as far as he could tell, thankfully. He glanced down, considering shrinking and pulling him out, but then realised that that would involve keeping him inside while he readjusted him from simply holding him in his hand to dragging him, and he wasn't sure if he had time for that. Shaking his head again, he smirked lopsidedly for a moment, before the smoke hit him again. He looked into the mirror again and focused. Going up.

His enormous frame seemed to surge outwards, his body practically piling on mass as he shot up several inches in mere seconds. His stance widened to accommodate his greater size, which sent his boots smashing through the floor, drawing a startled gasp from his muzzle. Thankfully, it seemed the house didn't have a basement, because he knew that if it did, he would be standing in it. Well, he would be sort of standing in it. His legs would be there, while his upper body would be racing towards the top floor. As he was thinking about that, his ears flicked reflexively as they brushed against the ceiling. He flinched and dropped lower to the ground, nearly dropping his SCBA mask. He snatched it up before it could hit the ground, but as he did so, they crash of his oxygen tank scraping against the wall behind him rang out. He grimaced as he stood back up, looking over his shoulder to see the gash in the plaster. Glancing back at the dent he had left, he could clearly see where his tank had been shoved into the wall, given it was deeper than his body's imprint, which while not as deep, although still impressively, or perhaps intimidatingly deep, was much broader. As he stood and reached his full height, his head gently pressed into the ceiling. He made to reach up with one hand before realising that he had his hands full. Shaking his head he decided the best bet was to just stand there and literally outgrow the house while ensuring the resident's safety. He placed the man up against the armour of his mighty chest as the ceiling began to quietly groan.

Exile gritted his teeth as his ears flattened against his head. His growing frame was placing more and more stress on the ceiling by the minute, the quiet groaning slowly rising into distressed creaks. As he kept growing, dust began to rain down on top of his broad shoulders as minute cracks began to spread through the plaster. The creaking and groaning was suddenly inter-spaced with a harsh, sharp crack of breaking timbers as the ceiling slowly began to rise around his head. One of his ears twitched, which sent it carving straight through the plaster as if it were a knife through hot butter, sending a drizzle of plaster dust down onto his head. He ducked lower, gently ruffling his fur to dislodge the dust before bringing his head up again, smacking into the ceiling. However, there was no pain this time, as if his substantially greater size also conferred greater physical resilience. The ceiling however, fared significantly more poorly than the Husky, cracking open in the face of so much Husky, exposing the attic above. Exile tilted his big muzzle up, grinning slightly at how trivially easy it was to utterly destroy the plaster and how easily the beam his nose had smacked into had snapped without even using just a part of his strength.

He blinked rapidly, trying to clear his eyes from the sting of the smoke, he looked around to see if there was anything of note. There was nothing much of interest, a stored Christmas tree here, an old armchair there, nothing to particular catch anyone's interest. Assuming, of course, they overlooked the enormous Husky's head bursting through the ceiling below that was now occupying about a third of the attic and was still getting bigger. Glancing down, Exile caught a glimpse of the man through the smoke, drawing a sigh of relief. He was still protected from the heat by his hand, but the smoke was still a major issue. With his mask and mirror held in his other hand, he looked back up to the ceiling as his ears began to brush up against it. It wouldn't be long now before he was literally too big for the house.

A little smile crossed his face, a sense of finality blossoming in his cavernous chest as his ears were pinned flat against the roof, plaster being gouged out with no effort on his part whatsoever. The ceiling let out a distressed groan before his ears smashed through, tearing the ceiling apart further with their twitching. His head bumped into the ceiling, utterly pulverising it. A booming crash caught his attention. Quickly looking down, he found his broad, muscular shoulders had smashed through the ceiling below, the silver gleam of his almost futuristic armour easily distinguishable from the dull beige of the flooring. He brought up a massive hand and waved the smoke away as best he could again, granting another glimpse of the man. Squinting, he leaned in as close as he could, given that his muzzle alone was taking up almost half of the attic. He was still breathing. Thank Mother Russia.

As he tilted his head back up, it smacked solidly into the roof above. He jumped at the impact, grimacing slightly as the cacophony of tiles being knocked loose and shattering against the ground outside rang out, easily audible over the groaning timbers and creaking pipes now that the roar of the flames was no more. He shook his head, forcing his thoughts back on track. This was probably - hopefully - the best way of getting the man outside and into fresh air safely. Well, as safely as could be given that he was literally growing through an entire house. Besides, it was far too late to back out now. His ears crashed through the roof, poking out into the cool air outside. With a renewed thrill, he curled the hand with the man in it to his chest and reached up with the other. The bulky, muscular limb smashed through the ceiling as he braced it against the roof, before pushing. The roof utterly disintegrated under the force, letting in a blast of clean, fresh air. For a moment, Exile was terrified that he had just set it up for a backdraft or flashover or something like that, but thankfully, there was no rush of flame or heat or anything. He let out a deep, heaving sigh of relief. He looked down at the mirror and let out another blast of vision, deciding it was time to get out of here, and he'd much rather step out of the house than burst through a wall. That was far too risky.

As the purple beam reflected from the mirror into his chest, Exile let out a gasp as he nearly dropped the mirror and his mask and tank. Stumbling slightly, his massive, muscular frame tearing the building apart where he crashed into it, he reached out and quickly dug his free hand into the building to steady himself. The house crumbled around his touch, the drywall reduced to dust in his expanding fingers as the building shook violently from the sheer force of the impact of his footsteps. He had to be at least 30 feet now, possibly even 40. How much did he weigh now? He must have been a ton at 14 feet, over twice his original weight, and doubling in height causes weight to increase by eight times, so he couldn't even imagine how much he weighed now. It must have been several tons by now, at the very least. Looking down and taking in the destruction he had caused so easily without even trying to, he let out a muttered curse of awe. Looking back up, he started as he realised his muzzle was now outside. He was taller than a two story house at this point, and he was still getting bigger. As his shoulders raced past the roof, he brought his hand up and held the man to his chest. He was so tiny now, he was barely three times the size of one of his fingers. Glancing down again, his jaw dropped as he realised that his huge chest was now level with the hole in the room, his huge, firm pectorals rapidly rising past the roof, which sank further and further down past his abdominals. He took a quick look back at the man. He was barely twice the size of a finger now. He was growing faster. He had to be at least 50 feet tall now, if his measurement was right, and he was rapidly approaching sixty. A solid one hundred feet should be enough for him to simply step out of the house.

Leaning over the wreckage of the house, he could spot the street, the distinctive flash of red of the Street Rover easily visible. As he looked, the flash of red continued to shrink as his viewpoint rose higher and higher by the second. A tremendous crashing sound snapped his attention to the house again, fearful of a structural collapse. With all the fire damage, a seventy foot tall dog-man could only be anything but good. Thankfully, it was only his waist rushing up through the hole, his bushy tail smashing through the roof and a section of wall behind him with trivial ease. He was almost at a hundred feet tall, already he was quickly reaching up to eighty feet, and his knees were already pushing past the roof. Now that the thrill of outgrowing the house had faded slightly, he could feel the internal walls caving in under the force his feet were exerting as they bowled over and crushed whatever furniture was in his way. He let out a chuckle at the sensation. It was almost like his feet were being tickled. Snorting with amusement, he shifted, shaking his whole body as he looked around, noting that no one was in sight, and if anyone was around, they were very well hidden. All he could hear was the groaning and cracking of timber and squeal of bending metal. Looking down, he had to estimate he was a solid hundred feet tall now. Ninety had come and gone without him even noticing. Letting out a breath of amazement, he gingerly lifted one of his thick, muscular legs out of the house, tentatively planting it down in the yard. He grimaced at the feeling of the earth giving way beneath his weight. He bit his lip, recalling the groaning of the floorboards beneath his weight. He was glad the house didn't have a basement.

After doing the same again, he turned, noting how the house was so tiny now, it was like a doll house. Glancing down at the man, he audibly gasped. He was so small, he wasn't even half the size of one of his fingers now. He looked around, never mind the house, the entire neighbourhood was tiny! He was a literal giant, he was several times the size of a house. It was a thrill like he'd never experienced before, no wonder Blitz loved it so much. He almost wanted to stay like this, but there was time for exploring possibly physics-defying sizes later - never mind their powers in the first place, naturally. He had work to do. He turned his gaze back to the man, and then to the mirror. A blast of green light shot forth from his eyes. First responders would be here any minute no doubt, he could hear sirens in the distance. He only hoped they hadn't seen him. But before they got here, there was still work to do to help this man.
